HOWARD AND MELVIN'S POINT OF VIEW . 33

dialogues.speaker: WATERIOLE
dialogues.text: The desert between Las Vegas and Tonopah, nothing but sag and greasewood. Sound -- in the distance, a motor. It com closer then fades, comes closer, fades. Pan off the waterhole in the direction of the sound. It approaches again, a figure appears in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE MOTORCYCLE 2
dialogues.text: Only the rider's back, silver-streaked hair. This gaunt f circles lazily in the moonlight, motorcycle tires rumblin the alkali. The circles get bigger and now biccer, and as comes around this time, the moonlight catches his face, a cratic cheekbones, a stringy beard, a pilot's light windb This is Howard, age 62, looks over 70.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER ALIGLE
dialogues.text: sweeping under the moon, wider and wider and now he speed towards the waterhole, giving the Harley full throttle.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE WATERHOLE 4
dialogues.text: A knoll running up to the edge of it.

dialogues.speaker: ON HOWARD 5
dialogues.text: heading straicht for the knoll, the chopper kicking up sa and greasewood and alkali behind it. Tremendous speed -- hits the knoll.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE MOTORCYCLE 6
dialogues.text: lioward flying through the air, his knees clutched around machine, his eyes wide with joy, laughter ringinc throuch desert.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ss 10 il 12 13

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The motorcycle clears the waterhole on the leap, Howard s in the saddle, lands in the mud on the other side, skids, churns, the tires spitting mud, now he rolls out on the desert again.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: sweeping into a figure eight, testing his motor now, pick up speed once more, heading straight for the knoll.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE KNOLL
dialogues.text: The motorcycle invisible, only the sound blasting through night, louder, louder, and now the motorcycie hits the to the knoll. A rock, a stone, something, it kicks, it stutt it flies short.

dialogues.speaker: ON HOWARD
dialogues.text: His face exactly the same as before, exultation at the le but there is no motorcycle under him now, only air.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: His momentum carrying him over the water and he lands wit crunch on the other side, his head hits the mud, a flare blood spurts from his ear.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD'S POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: His eye catching sight of his motorcycle fluttering down, landing with a splash, bubbling as it disappears into the waterhole.

dialogues.speaker: ON HOWARD
dialogues.text: picking himself up, stumbling across the desert, nothing silence around him, his feet kicking over the alkali. He trips, a bobcat swings past, looks, moves on.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: faltering, falling.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 13
dialogues.text: Ne picks himself up, his face scratched, his lips crusted with saliva, blood caked around his ear,

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD'S POINT OF VIEW 14
dialogues.text: Way in the distance, the headlights of a car.

dialogues.speaker: ON HOWARD 15
dialogues.text: He starts to raise his hand, almost furtively, but then h draws it back. He does not want to wave, He looks towards the moon, spins once like a shot~putter. Now he falls. The headlights pass on down the Interstate. Darkness.

dialogues.speaker: A SINGLE HEADLIGUT 16
dialogues.text: coning down the Interstate now. Sound -- a man singing. T song is horrible, the voice joyous. MELVIN (v.o.) (singing) ‘Well, he called his elves together To soup up his old sleigh So Rudolph and the other reindeer Could rest on Christmas Day....'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a face with no secrets, a cowlick and sideburns, looking younger than his thirties. Montgomery Ward pants and a shirt with cowboy roses.’ .

dialogues.speaker: NELVIN
dialogues.text: (singing) ‘He's got a million miles to travel And he'll do it in one day Oh that's because old Santa Claus Got a soured-up Santa sleich.' The song trails off into a hun as ?elvin pulls off onto t side of the road.  ss 18 19 20 21 22 23

dialogues.speaker: ON MELVIN 18
dialogues.text: undoing his fly. As he reaches into his pants, the sound a car in the distance, he quickly turns to hide himself, car passes. Now he reaches in again, but another car catches him in i lights.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Jeesuz. He climbs back into his car, stomps on the gas, and he zo off the highway and on to the alkali, up an old cattle ro Now he scuds to a stop, steps out onto the emptiness of t desert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pissing, sighing with relief, his sich mingling with the crackling of his urine as it hits the desert crust.

dialogues.speaker: ON MELVIN'S FACE 20
dialogues.text: Pleasure. The same pleasure he feels at eating, sleeping, defecating, copulating. Climbs back into his car. Starts up the motor, backs arou and the headlight catches a body lying in the deserted ca road.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN 21
dialogues.text: blinks. Squints, now he throws the car into low gear, rol slowly towards the body, stops a few feet away.

dialogues.speaker: ON MELVIN'S POINT OF VIEW 22
dialogues.text: The body doesn't move. Limp, dead.

dialogues.speaker: ON MELVIN 23
dialogues.text: following the shaft of the headlight, moving towards the Poised a step away. Now he crouches over it. A grunt. Melvin rolls it over. A beard, Howard's long hair. He lifts him, the headlight sh full into Howard's eyes, they open, flicker. Howard grunt again. CONTINUED.  ss 23 24 25 26

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Whut? Howard doesn't stir, doesn't answer. Melvin cradles Howar head, and the ear comes into view, fresh blood trickling the clotting. Melvin heaves Howard up, half-stumbling, ha carrying him towards the car, opens the passenger side an shovels him in.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN 24
dialogues.text: slamming the door shut. Now Melvin looks out towards the desert.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN'S POINT OF VIEW 25
dialogues.text: Only blackness and silence.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN 26
dialogues.text: climbs into the car on the driver's side, looks over at h passenger. Howard has scrunched himself into a corner, hi eyes are wide open now, and wild with terror. Melvin catc it. Melvin smiles, nothing from Howard. Melvin smiles again.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Whut's the matter, ol' buddy? Howard doesn't answer. He turns his head a little but as turns, blood oozes.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Whut are you doin’ out here? Silence again. Howard doesn't take his eyes off Melvin. Melvin leans toward him. Howard braces himself against th door.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: (peering into Howard's face) That ear don't look too good to me. You want a doctor? Howard shakes his head,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 26
dialogues.text: MELVIN (Cont'd) - There's a doctor in Beatty. That ain't but a few miles. Want to go to Beatty? Howard doesn't answer, just holds himself stiff against t door.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: We'll go to Beatty. Okay? He throws the car into gear, spins around and heads off t wards the interstate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin at the wheel, Howard hiding in the corner of the s offering Melvin as narrow a view of his face as possible. Suddenly a clatter, Melvin’s head whips around, Howard ha been taken with the shakes, terrible heaves, his teeth ch tering. Howard doubles over trying to warm himself, clutching bot shoulders cross-handed. Melvin reaches for the heater, clicks it on, nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: This ain't but a '66 -- damn heater never did work. Howard shudders again, a terrible whistling through his t Melvin bangs the heater with his fist.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: What do you mean it's okay? Now you just hold on there. Melvin pulls over to the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: ON MELVIN 28
dialogues.text: climbing out, opening the trunk. The trunk light shows tw giant plastic bags full of white powder, some horse harne a bow and arrow, a fishing rod, stuffed animals and puli- a ratty blanket and a pillow. He fishes out the blanket and pillow.  db 29

dialogues.speaker: TWO-SHOT
dialogues.text: Melvin leans towards Howard, drapes the blanket over him, does not drape. It is about the size of a shirt and the p low he places under his head would fit a doll. Howard regards them.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: They belong to my little girl. Can't go to sleep without’ her bumby. Melvin laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Shit. Howard shivers, the tiny blanket falls off him. He doesn' have the strength to pick it up. Melvin bends over to re- trieve it, as he does his head hits the dashboard and the heater whirrs on.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Well, damn! Damn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs again. Nothing fron Howard, still underneath th baby blanket, but now allowing his head to ease back ever slightly into the pillow. Melvin reaches his hand under the heater.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Warm as toast! You brought me luck, ol' buddy. That heater ain't worked since my wife kicked it last time I undressed her in the car. Howard stirs slightly, Melvin squints over at him. Melvin reaches across Howard, flips open the glove compartment - a torrent of bills and kleenex, a flashlight, half-eaten candy bars, some knitting needles, a pair of scissors, ol Dixie cups. Melvin rummages around in the mess.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I was lookin' for a band-aid.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Keep your eye on the road.

dialogues.speaker: CONT INULD
dialogues.text: db

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I said keep your eye on the road.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Well, up yours, ol' timer.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: to said ‘Up yours.’ Melvin rummages some more, more Papers fall out, Howard h tries to pick them up.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Leave 'em. They ain't but a bunch of collection notices. He snaps the glove compartment shut, looks over at Howard ear.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: We ain't gonna get to Beatty any too soon.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: No doctors.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: There ain't no doctors there. Just a public health nurse.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: No nurses.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You don't like nurses?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: No, I don't.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. They ride in silence. Howard is heaving now, Melvin watches him closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: mw

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Howard is 9 Rev. 12/12/78

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I'm not going to Beatty.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Aw, Jeezus.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I'm sorry ---

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Don't apologize ---

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I never apologize but I'll try to explain ---

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Don't explain!

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: You want to stop at Beatty, fine. I don't. I'm going to Vegas --- (x) silent. Melvin grits his teeth. Howard shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Man, you sure beat it, don't you? Squirrelly o1' wino layin' out there in the west 40, nobody sees you ‘til kingdom come -- I pick you up and what do you do? Rag me.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Nothing. I just think I'll rest a while.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You do that. You lay back now -- we're coming up to Beatty now -- you still don't want to stop?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: No, no stops, please.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You'll be sorry, you're gonna miss the knockers on the public health nurse there. Howard smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Soft, huh?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Do we stop at Beatty or no? Howard sighs.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: No. Melvin stomps on the gas.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Vegas, here we come, They drive for a long while in silence,

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD 30
dialogues.text: is silent, always watching Melvin, shifting, shaking some Melvin loose at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: You're not a bad driver.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I been driving since I was seven years old.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: How'd you reach the pedals?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Make it nine. I had most of my growth by nine.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I'll bet you did. Jacking off in that trailer.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: How'd you know I lived in a trailer?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Didn't you Say so?

dialogues.speaker: NELVIN
dialogues.text: They was my three brothers in the trailer with me.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: In one trailer?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: mw 30

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 12 Rev.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Two of us slept on cots and two on the old dinette table. We didn't have nothing but an outhouse. I remember the first day I went to school I peed in the water fountain.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Interesting.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Took me right down to the Salvation Army, bought me shoes and carted me back to school.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What'd you say your name was?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Melvin Dummar.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: You're kidding me, Melvin. Melvin smiles, looks over at Howard.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Hey, ol' buddy. You want to do ne a favor?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Depends on what it is.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I've written a song.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: No ---

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: It's a Christmas number -- ‘Santa's Souped-Up Sleigh." 12/12/78 30 (X)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 1fl 30

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Oh God.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I sent it to Hollywood Talent Searchers. You know you give them the lyric -- they write you the music -- seventy dollars and worth every penny -- you want to hear it?

dialogues.speaker: HOWAPD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Here's how it goes -- (sings) "Well, he called his elves together To soup up his oid sleigh So Rudolph and the other reindeer Could rest on Christmas Day 'He's got a million miles to travel And he'll do it in one day Oh that's because old Santa Claus Got a souped up Santa sleigh'

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Enough, sir —--

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Wait till you hear the talk part ~~ a dramatic narration like Red Sovine -- (speaks) ‘Now listen there fat man Just because you're Santa Claus That don't give you the right To come around and making all that noise In the middle of the night. Now I don't care who you are, fat man You get those reindeer off my roof --~'

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Please stop -~-

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUFD
dialogues.text: 1fl 30

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: My ear.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Told you we should have stopped at Beatty.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: It's the sound.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: What do you mean, the sound?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Your song.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You're cruel, man, you know that? You're a cruel man.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I have an aversion to song.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You never sung in your life?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Not if I could help it.

dialogues.speaker: MFLVIN
dialogues.text: That's how you got to be an ol! asshole. Now you come along on the chorus -- (sincs) ‘He's got a rocket burnin’ mighty quick . Turnin' souped up Santa's sleigh He'll come in like a streak of light And he'll blast off right away...' You got that?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Now sing along with me. Or you gonna walk to Vegas. (sings) ‘He's got a rocket. burnin' mighty quick! Motions to Howard to join in.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUFD
dialogues.text: 1fl 30

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (mumbling; gingerly singing) 'Turnin’ souped up santa s sleigh'

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Now you're gettin' it! Once more --- Howard starts to sing.

dialogues.speaker: FOVARD
dialogues.text: (singina) "He's got a rocket burnin' mighty quick Turnin' souped up Santa's sleigh....'

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: (speaking) ‘Now now, Mr. Fat Man, what are you trying to do? Now that chimney’s too small and you might fall -- so you just get down off that roof! Melvin points to Howard and Howard joins in.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD AND MELVIN
dialogues.text: (singing) ‘When you hear those rockets roar You'll know Santa's on his way But he'll be back again next year In his souped up Santa's sleigh!’ Howard seems pleased with himself.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You done it! And you want to know something?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You weren't bad.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Now you sing me one of your songs ---

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I don't know any songs -~-

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 1fl 30

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Anythin'. ‘Stop And Smell The Roses,' My Woman, My Woman, My Wife' -- whatever you like ---

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I don't know any songs. My father was the singer in the family. ‘When The Sunset Turns The Ocean's Blue To Gold,' 'Bill Bailey.' (imitates) "Sonny, you do the verse, I'll take the chorus.' And off he'd go.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: What songs do you know?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Me? Nothing ~- (shrugs) "Bye Bye Blackbird.' -

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: There you go! Melvin punches Howard in the arm.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Lay it on me, ol' timer.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Don't be crazy.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: ‘Ladeez and gentlemen -- to wind up our program tonight -- and I want y'all t'drive home safely ~- y'hear? ~~ we got a brand new number by an ol' ol' timer -- he's been a pickin' and a strummin' for many a year -- so let's hear it for this little ditty -- the ol' timer and "Bye Bye Blackbird!" ~- take it, ol' timer!!' Howard looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Let me out. Melvin winks.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Come on. Howard starts to hum a little.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Ooh, that's nice ~- did I hear a word?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: ‘Bye, Bye, Blackbird.’

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: There she goes.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: {starting to sing faintly) "Pack up all my cares and woes Here I go Singing low’

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD AND MELVIN
dialogues.text: (singing) "Bye, bye, blackbird!' Howard is gaining strength.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (singing) ‘Where somebody waits for me Sugar's sweet So is she'

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD AND MELVIN
dialogues.text: (singing) ‘Bye, bye, blackbird!' Melvin turns to Howard, presenting him like an emcee.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (singing) ‘No one here can love and understand me Oh what hard luck stories they all hand me Make my bed and light the light I'll arrive Late tonight Blackbird -.--'

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: (sinaing) "Blackbird!'

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD AND MELVIN
dialogues.text: . (singing . together) ‘Blackbird Bye! pye!' Howard's face is aglow with joy, but no more so than Melv

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Hey! Melvin reaches out his hand -- Howard gives it a boogie slap.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I like that song -- clean up that lyric a little and she'll take right off. Suddenly Howard withdraws -- dim and distant. They ride again in silence. Melvin looks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: How're you doin?'

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I'm fine. (after a moment) So where are you going now?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Home to Gabbs. Bringin' back (xX) some stuff for our trailer my : sister wanted to get rid of.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What do you do in Gabbs? (xX)

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I work in the Mag Ox Plant. You know -- Maalox -- you get an ulcer ---

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I know, I know ---

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You know what?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I know Maalox comes from magnesium oxide. All the Jews in New York drink it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Melvin looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Well that's more than most people know.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Silence. I wasn't complimenting you. That was just a comment.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Still I appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Don't bother me, dirty work or no. Was a milkman once -- used to stink of sour milk. Now I smell like Maalox.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What a shame.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I remember once. -- I was delivering milk in the middle of the night -- and it come to me -- why don't I get a job on graveyard like some of them old gals' husbands -- so I went around to McDonnell Douglas and Hughes ---

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: And what happened?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Nuthin.'

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: What a shame.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You keep saying 'what a shame! ~--—

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I might have done something.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Done what?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I'm Howard Hughes. Melvin's head swivels, he squints over at Howard beside h Now he looks back at the road. Suddenly he turns back to Howard.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I said I'm Howard Hughes. Melvin stifles a smile, tries to look very serious, steal another look over at Howard, now he shakes his head to himself.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Well I believe in anybody callin' themselves anything they want to.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I appreciate that.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN'S POINT OF VIEW -. 31
dialogues.text: Windshield, a raindrop, then another. Then a sudden downpour, a desert shower, stopping almost as soon as it starts.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN'S POINT OF VIEW 32
dialogues.text: The rain clearing, just a gray sky. He opens the window. Howard opens his window.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: (breathing in) Greasewood.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (breathing in) Sage.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Nothing like the smell of the desert after the rain.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Greasewood and sage. They roll along for a while.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD AND MELVIN'S POINT OF VIEW . 33
dialogues.text: way in the distance, the casinos. and hotels rising out o desert -- Las Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN'S POINT OF VIEW 35
dialogues.text: rolling into Las Vegas on the boulevard. The blaze of neo lighting up his and Howard's face.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Can I let you off at the Salvation Army?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: No thanks. What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: We'll keep pluggin'.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Let me off at The Sands. Nelvin drives down Las Vegas Blvd., and pulls in at The S

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Over there. Nelvin drives around the back, towards the bungalows, slo about LOMPH.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Stop ---

dialogues.speaker: NELVIN
dialogues.text: Right here?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: This is the place.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 36

He tips the urn, now releases the spigot, the coffe spurts out. Follow the coffee from the spout to the floor. On the flo a hole has been worn, like a crater, from the drippings o the coffee.

dialogues.text: I don't want to go to San Francisco, Red. But I'll hitch a ride with you to Reno.

dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You dropped your cigarette! Smoke pours up from under Little Red. He jumps out of the car. -

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You little red asshole! Melvin whips off his jacket, starts beating away at the smoking seat. Little Red is running around outside of the car, cooling himself. Finally, Melvin who is making no headway, rips the whole seat out from its slides, throws it in the road.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Now you drive. And stay awake! Little Red dutifully climbs into the driver's seat. Melvi lays down in the rear, goes to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.text: climbing out of the car, walking slowly to a high gate ma of hurricane fencing. He tries the knob, nothing happens. Jiggles it. A Voice booms out over the desert.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.text: You got a little red~haired guy in there?

dialogues.text: Name?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Little Red.

dialogues.text: Just a minute, Melvin cups his hands, blows air through them, stomps his feet in the cold.

dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Hin,

dialogues.speaker: VOICE

dialogues.text: 'Ma'am' ---

dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Let me get my buddy.

Come back as witnesses anytime. (reaches into her drawer) And here's some party packets -- five dollars free at Caesar's Palace -- five dollars free at the Sands -- five dollars free at the Desert Inn -- Love ya both!

dialogues.speaker: ON THE BENCH 209
dialogues.text: Judge Hayes, a short, unhealthy-looking young man. He ben down towards Melvin.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HAYES
dialogues.text: Melvin, turn your chair around and face me. Melvin turns his chair around.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HAYES
dialogues.text: Are you lying, Melvin?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HAYES
dialogues.text: Melvin, I want you to know there is a still, small voice that many people are blessed with that tells them when the truth is being spoken. It has been said, ‘that doth it profit a man if he gain the whole world yet lose his own soul?' If you are lying, Nelvin, which you are, in my opinion, your soul may be in jeopardy, but I am not con- cerned about your soul, Melvin, right now I am concerned about your hide, because if I find that you are lying before this Court, I will make it a special duty to have a piece of your hide. TI will direct that the district attorney bring a criminal prosecution against you and I will make it my special project that if you are convicted I will reconmend that you do prison time. And I want you to know Nevada State Prison is no country club like the Gabbs local jail or wherever you have served tine. If you're lying,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Judge -110 20° JUDGE HAYES (Cont'd) you're going straight to Nevada State Prison. All right, Melvin?

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Melvin surrounded by his relatives and Bonnie and Lynda a

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: mw #00433 lll

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 210
dialogues.text: the children. Syvella, his sister, holds up a sign "We're with you, Melvin!" The court bell rings, everybody hustles back, Melvin find himself standing for a moment with Lynda and Darcy and Fa

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA
dialogues.text: You're doin' good.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA
dialogues.text: Real good. Lynda hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA
dialogues.text: Bob ---

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Who's he?

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA
dialogues.text: My husband wishes you luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you thank hin. The bells rings again. Melvin picks up Faron.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: (to Darcy) You hold on to Faron, honey. Give your mama a rest. Darcy takes Faron.

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA
dialogues.text: What happens now?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I got to face the meanest lawyer in the whole dann world.  211 212

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold Rhoden, an urbane five-foot seven-inch from Los Angeles, is examining Harold.

dialogues.speaker: RODEN
dialogues.text: How did you open the envelope?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Steamed it open.

dialogues.speaker: RHODEN
dialogues.text: Why didn't you take a knife or a letter opener and open it the way everybody else opens an envelope?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I was scared.

dialogues.speaker: RHODEN
dialogues.text: What were you scared of?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: That it might actually be true.

dialogues.speaker: RHODEN
dialogues.text: Why was that frightening?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: RHODEN
dialogues.text: Had you ever performed this little act before of steaming open an envelope?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RHODEN
dialogues.text: What were the occasions for this activity?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Looking at letters that my ex-wife had written to her boyfriend and what have you, before she could mail then.

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA 212
dialogues.text: She smiles at Melvin reassuringly. Syvella raises the sig  db #00433 113 Rev, 12/12/78

dialogues.speaker: RHODEN
dialogues.text: Why did you take the will to the (%} church?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Because I was too afraid to take it anywhere else.

dialogues.speaker: RHODEN
dialogues.text: Say that again. Melvin hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I thought they would help me.

dialogues.speaker: RHODEN
dialogues.text: Mr. Dummar, you believe, do you not, that if in the name of God, you lie, God will hear you and you will incur his wrath. You believe that don't you, Mr. Dummar?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. Suddenly Rhoden darts across the room, snatches up from t counsel desk a weather-beaten Bible.

dialogues.speaker: RHODEN
dialogues.text: Mr, Dummar, I have a Bible here. Please stand up. Melvin stands.

dialogues.speaker: RHODEN
dialogues.text: Put your hand on it, raise your right hand.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 213
dialogues.text: Melvin raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: RHODEN
dialogues.text: Do you swear before God that this story about how that will was left to you is the truth?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: RHODEN
dialogues.text: All right, sit down. Melvin sits.

dialogues.speaker: RHODEN
dialogues.text: That's all for now. Mr. Freese? Freese, a Los Angeles lawyer for Hughes' relatives, heads straight for Melvin.

dialogues.speaker: FREESE
dialogues.text: Can you give me one reason on earth why this strange man would have left that will with you, Melvin Dummar?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: No, I don't. I've been wondering that myself.

dialogues.speaker: FREESE
dialogues.text: Did you come up with an answer?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: No, I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: FREESE
dialogues.text: Melvin, isn't it true you can't come up with an answer because it never happened that way?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: That is the way it happened.

dialogues.speaker: FREESE
dialogues.text: Well, Melvin, if it meant eternal damnation in hell would you just say it still happened that way?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Yes, I would.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ss 213

dialogues.speaker: FREESE
dialogues.text: Melvin, you know, don't you, that perhaps other than your relatives, there is nobody in this courtroom who believes you. You know that, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I don't know what people believe. And I don't care. People have been calling me an asshole all my life. And it don't matter either way. . The courtroom erupts, Judge Hayes slams his gavel. Melvin leans back. Darcy waves. Melvin waves back.

dialogues.speaker: FREESE
dialogues.text: Let's go back to when you got the will, and everybody celebrated and you were a national hero, Melvin. And they asked you about your getting over a hundred million dollars and I think you sobbed, choked, went into a sort of deep, heavy mood. I was kind of caught by it as I watched it on TV, but then my wife said, 'My God, it is just like the women on the game shows!' I don't watch the game shows myself, but soon after I learned you had gotten your wife on one. Melvin looks at Lynda. She waves.

dialogues.speaker: FREESE
dialogues.text: Let's make a deal, Melvin. Tell us the real truth. I know the dream is so much better -- My God, I was a child in Minnesota during the Depression and I can remember, kind of hoping one of those trucks going by might have a box of chewing gum on it and it would fall off. That was the dream -- it never happened. And I never tried to make it happen. Freese takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: FREESE
dialogues.text: Let's make a deal, Melvin. Tell us the truth and you know what I'll give you -- I'll plead in your be- half a whole day to have the judge give you probation. But if you don't tell the truth, I'll do my utmost to see you never breathe another free breath in the state of Nevada. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HAYES
dialogues.text: Mr. Dummar, do you wish to make any response to what I would characterize as an offer from Mr. Freese?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I would like to say I don't know if the will is a forgery or not. If it is, I didn't do it. And if it isn't -- (shrugs) I guess it's for real.

dialogues.speaker: FREESE
dialogues.text: That's no deal, Melvin.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Freese stalks back to the counsel table. He is exhausted. Dilworth, another lawyer, rises unsteadily. Looks at Melv

dialogues.speaker: DILWORTH'S POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: Fresh as a daisy, his head tucked into his neck, he is sn his fingers, trying to get a rise out of Faron.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN'S POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: raises Faron's hand with hers, waves to Melvin.  db 216 #00433 117 Rev. 12/12/78

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Xx) Melvin is packing, Roger Dutson, Melvin's lawyer enters, broad smile on his face. Melvin looks up.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You did it, Melvin. The Judge set a trial for July 6 ---

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: That means he believes you. On July 6th, they're going to deter- mine the validity of the will. Like he said, 'It's the only will we've got,' plus the positive (X) testimony by the handwriting ex- perts. I think the will is going to be admitted to probate. You're going to get your inheritance.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Of course it's going to be a long, long road -- but we've won the first battle. I can tell -- the T-Shirt people called again -- Rockwood Dairy says they'll lift the garnishees on your entire @arnings’at the filling station ---

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: The T-shirts are an easy fifteen thousand. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: No, thanks ---

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: But you can use the cash --- ‘ CONTINUED  1f1 216

dialogues.speaker: MPLVIN
dialogues.text: You want to cet naid?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: No no no -- it's just they started paving the freeway today down fror the gas station -- within two weeks. you're qoina to be pretty lonely up there.

dialogues.speaker: YFLVIN
dialogues.text: Don't worry about me. Roger sighs,

dialogues.speaker: ROGFR
dialogues.text: Well, you won, Mel ~--

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Then what are you so sad about?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: I just hope you don't have any illusions. They'll fight it through every court they can -- the relatives -- Summa -- meanwhile the government'll be taking out taxes -- the states'11 be taking out taxes -- the lawyers'll be taking out legal fees -- the money's going to be siphoned off ---

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I knew all that the day I found the will. POGEP. You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Melvin Dummar's never going to see 156 million dollars -- in fact he's never going to see a dime. Melvin closes his suitcase: puts it on a cart and pushes it out the door.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: But Howard Hughes sang Melvin Durmar's song. Howard Hughes sang 'Santa's Souped Up Sleigh.'

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The door slams.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: (bewildered) ‘Santa's' what, Melvin? Melvin has gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melvin rolls up in Little Ped's old car. Lynda is standin on the sidewalk with Faron and Darcy.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Sorry ~~-

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA
dialogues.text: It's okay. Gave me a chance to get them fed. You really want to do this?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: See my kids? Get them out of that smog? You kiddin'? Lynda looks at the car doubtfully.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Little Red lent it to me for the trip. He went back up with Bonnie in the tow truck. (to Darcy) Hop in, kids. There's Lifesavers and comic books back there. Darcy pushes Faron into the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: I bought a pair of shoes for Faron -- help him try them on, Sister. Darcy takes Faron's shoes off.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You got money to get back to

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA
dialogues.text: Don't worry about me, Melvin.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: (smiles) It's in my blood.

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA
dialogues.text: You're not going to hassle me when I want them back end of the summer?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You've got my word.

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA
dialogues.text: That's what I'm afraid of.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Howsa bout you takin' me back the end of the summer? Lynda smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA
dialogues.text: You're married, Melvin. Melvin shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: So are you. Lynda smiles again.

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA
dialogues.text: I do miss it sometimes, Melvin ~~ it was always exciting. Lousy -- but exciting.

dialogues.speaker: MFLVIN
dialogues.text: We could make it that way again.

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA
dialogues.text: It is now. Lynda smiles once rore.

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA
dialogues.text: Give us a kiss. She kisses him hard. He blushes.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: End of the summer?

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA
dialogues.text: Maybe. Now he piles into the car.

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA
dialogues.text: (yelling) G'bye, kids! But Darcy is reading a comic book out loud to Faron. They don't even look up.

dialogues.speaker: TONOPAH HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: (x) Melvin rolling along in Little Red's car, Darcy and Faron have moved into the front seat, sound asleep. Melvin rests his hand on Darcy's forehead.

dialogues.speaker: ON MELVIN THROUGH WINDSHIELD 219
dialogues.text: (x) Windshield, a raindrop, then another. Then a sudden downpour, a desert shower, stopping almost as soon as it starts.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN'S POINT OF VIF 220
dialogues.text: The rain clearing, just a gray sky. He opens the window. Howard opens his window.

dialogues.speaker: ON MELVIN
dialogues.text: breathing in the desert after the shower.

dialogues.speaker: ELVIN
dialogues.text: Greasewood.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: (breathing in) Sage.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Nothing like the smell of the desert after the rain.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Greasewood and sage.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 22
dialogues.text: They roll along for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about letting me drive?

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Just for a little while.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Drive?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I'm a goddamn good driver ---

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: You haven't driven a car since they put out the last Hudson.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: I'm a goddamn good driver. I'11l bet you.

dialogues.speaker: ON MELVIN 222
dialogues.text: He looks at Howard.

dialogues.speaker: ON HOWARD 223
dialogues.text: waiting.

dialogues.speaker: ON MELVIN
dialogues.text: Smiles, pulls off the road.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: When we get to Vegas, I'll run her into town. Howard hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN
dialogues.text: Take the wheel, ol' timer. Howard gets out and Melvin slides over.  1fl 225 226 227 228 #00433 123°

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN'S POINT OF VIFV 225
dialogues.text: Howard looking carefully at the dashboard. Very slowly he puts the car into gear, very slowly he releases the brake, and very slowly he rolls it out onto the road.

dialogues.speaker: ON MELVIN AND HOWARD . 226
dialogues.text: Melvin watching as Howard drives. Howard watching Melvin watching him. Now Melvin's head begins to nod. His eyes close.

dialogues.speaker: ON HOWARD. 227
dialogues.text: Driving, now he turns, sneaks a look at Melvin who is sound asleep beside him. Gives the car a little cas and becins to sina.

dialogues.speaker: HOMAPD
dialogues.text: {singing} quietly) "Make my bed And light the light I'll arrive Late tonight Blackbird! Blackbird! Bye! Bye!!' Howard props his arm out the window, adjusts the mirror, now he gives the car more gas. He is very happy.

dialogues.speaker: MELVIN'S CAR 228
dialogues.text: xolling down the highway to Las Vegas. From it ---: HOWARD (v.0.) (singing) ‘Pack up all my cares and woes Singin’ low Here I go Bye bye blackbird....' The car becomes a dot. It never disappears, nor does the music end.

dialogues.speaker: THE END
